column3: Some women add length or fullness to their hair by combining others’ hair with their own.

column2: Hair_ Weft and Weave - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The two most common methods of attaching purchased hair are the sew-in technique and the bonded-glue technique. There are advantages and disadvantages to both methods.

column2: Hair_ Weft and Weave - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The sew-in technique has a more natural appearance and involves braiding the purchased hair into a woman’s natural hair.

column2: Hair_ Weft and Weave - National Council of Teachers of Mathematics
column3: The bonded-glue technique is preferred by women whose natural hair is thinning. (One downside is that the glue can leave a sticky residue.) The resulting look is called a weave and requires regular maintenance appointments. At a typical weave maintenance appointment, a stylist will wash the hair, check for any unsightly issues, and/or reapply the bonded glue.
